Award.AwardTitle: NRI: Collaborative Research: Co-Exploration using Science Hypothesis Maps

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project studies a new approach to exploration. In this approach, the explorer's description of where to go is not prescribed by a path, but instead by a model of what the explorer believes. In the context of a human scientist and robotic explorer working together, this approach transforms the co-robotic relationship into a collaboration in which the human and robot work together to fill in gaps in knowledge to make discoveries. The science hypothesis map is the structure in which human scientists initially describe their belief about the world and in which the belief state evolves as the robotic explorer collects information.

This project addresses a pressing and understudied area of human/robot interaction: it directly tackles the challenges of human scientist interaction with remote robotic explorer by crafting a representation of the environment that is expressive and intuitive for the human while quantifying information to enable meaningful robotic decisions. The hypothesis map formulation is a novel and radical departure from our prior work which has focused on human goal selection and robotic autonomy. It has the potential to revolutionize exploration robotics by changing the nature of the relationship between human and robot from supervisory control to shared information discovery.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Exploration today is guided by scientists crafting a plan that they believe will lead to discovery and success in reaching their scientific goals. An exploration path is formed from their knowledge of the investigation and their expectations and biases about where and how to best gather information. Our goal is to improve the operational efficiency and science yield of robotic exploration--to collect more and better data.

 

This research addresses a pressing and understudied area of human/robot interaction: it directly tackles the challenges of human scientist interaction with a robotic system by crafting representation of the environment that is expressive and intuitive for the human while quantifying information to enable meaningful decisions for the robot. Science Hypothesis Maps represent arrangements and classifications of properties of an environment with corresponding probabilities of this interpretation.  The hypothesis map formulation is a radical departure from prior work which has focused on human goal selection and robotic execution. This work has the potential to revolutionize robotic exploration.

 

These benefits will accrue to applications beginning with planetary exploration.  Robotic missions to the Moon, Mars and outer planets can traverse tens of kilometers and collect gigabytes of data, but have limited communication bandwidth and opportunity.  This motivates science autonomy in a rover that can interpret the data it collects and to choose its activities during periods of isolation. There are broader impacts on Earth.  Robotic exploration of the mostly-uninhabited oceans and biosphere could transform Earth science, but only if we can overcome the reliance on human micromanagement. For example, fleets of robotic craft are measuring the ocean and new commercial enterprises in micro-air vehicles observe everything from traffic to agricultural productivity. With the cost of commercial robotics dropping for everything from quadrotors to seagliders, operator time and communication have become the most significant barrier to scaling these systems.

 

The algorithms and software for hypothesis mapping and exploration planning created in this project were implemented and deployed on the mobile robot (Image 1). The robot's onboard visual-infrared spectrometer was used to collect data for spectroscopic analysis and to update its map.  The uncertainty (entropy) in its map was used to decide where to go and what to observe with its spectrometer.  In a few tens of steps it was able to build a mineralogical map over hundreds of meters.

 

We applied deep learning to enhancing signal reconstruction, specifically a convolutional neural network was trained to use a few wavelengths of multi-spectral data to predict  continuous high-resolution spectra. (Image 2) The improvement in data quality showed that low-resolution remote sensing data, such as from satellite-based instruments using a few wavelengths of light, could be used to reconstruct the high-resolution spectra collected on the ground and used in classification. This technology enables high-resolution, regional geologic classification (by highly accurate mineral identification) using low-resolution imaging spectroscopy. (Image 3)

 

The hypothesis mapping method was also applied to the marine science, to study of the benthic environment and model shallow water coral, algae (seaweed), and sand. In this application orbital multi-spectral imagery served as the initial hypothesis map and aerial hyperspectral imagery was sampled as the in situ measurement. The exploration planner produced information-optimal sample locations and created a coral map verified against ground truth (scuba survey). This work is being extended to regional and global coral reef mapping.

 

This work has progressed from initial formulation of the hypothesis mapping concept, through implementation, to application in two domains (mineralogical and benthic exploration and mapping). We have quantified performance in extensive simulation studies and verified these improvements in real- world use. This project has proven the efficacy of the hypothesis mapping concept for robotic exploration and has validated in extensive simulation studies, using actual instrument data, and in field experiments conducted by a robot with scientific instrumentation, planning and mapping in real time.  The work is now poised for broader application.
